title: Fire fighters reveal cause of huge electricity substation blaze in Leicester | Leicester Mercury
text:
Fire fighters reveal cause of huge electricity substation blaze in Leicester By danjmartin | Posted: March 29, 2017 0 COMMENTS SHARES Comments (0) 
The fire service has revealed the cause of a huge blaze at a city electricity substation. 
Fire fighters say the inferno at the Western Power complex in Ravensbridge Drive was sparked by an electrical short circuit. 
The fire, at the 132,000-volt substation last Tuesday, caused a major electricity outage, temporarily cutting power to 45,000 homes and businesses . 
Drivers were stuck in jams as traffic lights failed . A plume of thick, black smoke was visible for miles and residents and workers at nearby businesses reported hearing explosions. 
Fire crews were initially restricted to a defensive firefighting operation , unable to tackle the 8,000 litres of blazing insulation oil until getting the all-clear that power to the site was off. 
Read more: Leicester Mercury readers' video of major fire in Leicester city centre 
Hundreds of litres of concentrated foam were then diluted before being pumped on to the red-hot metal of one of the two electricity transformers. Although the blaze was under control it re-ignited several times in the following days. 
At the weekend, contractors for Western Power were on site carrying out demolition work to clear the damaged remains of the substation. 
A Western Power spokesman said a new substation has been built off site and will be transported to Leicester.

The piece of kit, which is about the size of a house, will take some time to connect up but the firm hopes it will be operational within 20 days. 
He said the company's own investigation into the cause of the blaze was continuing and that the fire service explanation - of an electrical short circuit - might be 'an oversimplification."
